message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s inability to extend his wrist or fingers suggests injury to the radial nerve, which is responsible for wrist and finger extension. The preserved motor and sensation in the elbow rules out lower trunk and main median nerve injury. The preservation of sensation on most of the volar surface, but not the first dorsal web space, suggests that the injury may be distal to the radial sensory nerve branch. The recurrent motor branch of the median nerve does not control wrist or finger extension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has preserved motor and sensation in his right elbow but is unable to extend his wrist or fingers, which suggests damage to the radial nerve that innervates these muscles. The preserved sensation on most of the volar surface excludes the main median nerve. The first dorsal web space is innervated by the radial nerve and the recurrent motor branch of the median nerve, but the fact that the patient has preserved sensation on most of the volar surface suggests that the main median nerve is not injured. The lower trunk does not innervate the muscles or sensory areas described in the question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has preserved motor function in his elbow, which rules out a lower trunk injury. The inability to extend wrist and fingers suggests a radial nerve injury. The lack of sensation in the first dorsal web space indicates the damage is between the brachial plexus and the branching point of the sensory branch of the radial nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s inability to extend his wrist or fingers indicates damage to the radial nerve. The preserved motor and sensation in the elbow suggest that the lower trunk and main median nerve are intact. Damage to the recurrent motor branch of the median nerve would affect the thenar muscles and not the wrist or finger extension.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with limited wrist and finger extension, which suggests an injury to the radial nerve. The preserved motor and sensation in the elbow suggest that the injury is distal to the lower trunk, and the preserved sensation on most of the volar surface suggests that the main median nerve is likely intact. The lack of sensation in the first dorsal web space suggests that the recurrent motor branch of the median nerve is also not affected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has preserved motor and sensation in his right elbow, so it’s not likely to be lower trunk or main median nerve injury. The fact that he is unable to extend his wrist or extend his fingers further and has no sensation to the first dorsal web space but has preserved sensation on most of the volar surface suggests a radial nerve injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest damage to the radial nerve, which is responsible for wrist and finger extension. The preserved motor and sensation in the elbow and volar surface, along with the lack of sensation in the first dorsal web space, further support the diagnosis of radial nerve injury. All other options are less likely based on the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has preserved motor and sensation in his right elbow, which means the main median nerve is intact. The patient is unable to extend his wrist or extend his fingers further, which indicates a radial nerve injury. The lack of sensation in the first dorsal web space further supports a radial nerve injury, as this area is supplied by the radial nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has preserved motor function of the elbow which rules out Lower trunk injury. The fact that the patient is unable to extend his wrist or fingers further suggests a radial nerve injury. The preserved sensation on most of the volar surface and lack of sensation to the first dorsal web space further confirm this diagnosis. The other options would have different presentation of symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has preserved motor function of his elbow, but he is unable to extend his wrist and fingers. This suggests injury to the radial nerve, which supplies these muscles. The lack of sensation in the first dorsal web space confirms the involvement of the radial nerve, which innervates this area. The other options do not correspond to the patient's symptoms.
